entry.title: VideoBrain Family Computer (vidbrain)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

The VideoBrain Family Computer (model 101) is an 8-bit home computer manufactured by Umtech Incorporated, starting in 1977.
It was built around the F8 processor from Fairchild Semiconductor, and featured 1KB of RAM and a 4KB ROM. It was able to output 384 x 336 graphics and 128 x 56 semigraphic characters in 16 colors, and sound to a connected television set through an RF connector.

By far its most striking feature was the 36-key keyboard - though the keyboard of the VideoBrain was poorly designed and difficult to use, keyboards were not available on any of the more common video game consoles of the time. The system also features four joystick ports, a cartridge connector, and an expansion port.

15 games (~38 MB)

entry.title: Tiger LCD Handhelds (tiger)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

Tiger is most well known for their low-end handheld electronic game systems with LCD screens. Each unit contains a fixed image printed onto the handheld that can be seen through the screen. Static images then light up individually in front of the background that represent characters and objects, similar to numbers on a calculator or digital clock.

In addition to putting out some of its own games, Tiger was able to secure licenses from many of the time's top selling companies to sell their own versions of games such as Capcom's Street Fighter II, Sega's Sonic 3D Blast, and Konami's Castlevania II: Simon's Quest. Later, Tiger introduced what they called "wrist games". These combined a digital watch with a scaled-down version of a Tiger handheld game.

entry.title: Dreamcast Visual Memory Unit (svmu)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

The Visual Memory Unit is a memory card used by Sega's Dreamcast console. Unlike other memory cards, the VMU has a small LCD display and a set of buttons that resemble those on a Game Boy portable console. The VMU plugs directly into the joypad. During play, a small screen displays game information, pictures, and hints.

Some games, such as Sonic Adventure, allow you to copy special software to the VMU so that you can play the game without connecting to a console. In addition, the memory card allows you to see the current time thanks to the built-in clock. The VMU is available in several colors, the most common being blue (made of transparent blue plastic) and white.

entry.title: Bandai RX-78 (rx78)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

The Bandai RX-78 is a Japanese 8-bit microcomputer manufactured by Bandai. Its name comes from the RX-78-2 Gundam. It was released in July 1983, and employed a SHARP LH0080A (Zilog Z80A clone) CPU. It ran at a clock speed of 4.1 MHz, and shipped with 30 KB of RAM and 8KB of ROM. It had two joystick ports in a proprietary format using 8-pin DIN connectors.

The computer can generate 27 colors, created from 3 levels of intensity of each RGB channel, arranged into VRAM video planes, with a maximum resolution of 192×184 pixels, and is capable of displaying 30 x 23 text characters using a 6x8 pixel font. Sound was generated by the Texas Instruments SN76489 chip, providing 3 voices in four octaves and noise generator. Software was available on cartridges or cassettes.

entry.title: Pecom 64 (pecom64)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

The Pecom 64 was a computer designed for education and home use in Serbia in the mid-1980s. It had a CDP 1802B processor, 32 KB of RAM, and a cassette tape for storage. It could display text and graphics on a TV screen, and produce sound through two channels. It had a programmable character set and a reconfigurable keyboard.

It was compatible with some software and hardware from other computers, such as the Cosmac VIP and the Commodore 64. It was one of the first computers made in Yugoslavia.

entry.title: Philips P2000T (p2000t)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

The Philips P2000T home computer was Philips' first real entry in the home computer market in 1980, after the Philips Videopac G7000 game system (better known in North America as the Magnavox Odyssey²) which they already sold to compete with the Atari 2600 and similar game systems.

Philips used components they already produced for other markets (television sets and dictation machines) to quickly design a small computer system. It was partially designed by Austrian professor Dieter Hammer. They also copied the ROM cartridge system from their Videopac G7000 game system. One of these cartridges contained Microsoft BASIC. It was also possible to use cassette tape floppies.

entry.title: Othello Multivision (multivision)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

The Othello Multivision FG-1000 developed by Tsukuda Original was one of the more well-known SC-3000 clones.
The console was made of a keyboard with a cartridge slot and a tiny joystick grafted on to the right side of the keyboard.
The Multivision could play any SG-1000 or SC-3000 game, but it also came bundled with Othello (hence the name) and had a handful of exclusive games packaged under the Multivision branding.

A second model of the Multivision, the FG-2000, was released in 1984 with a built-in directional pad instead of a joystick and a port that allowed a second actual controller, but by then, the Multivision’s fate on the marketplace had been sealed. Both versions sold poorly, and as a result, are incredibly rare.

entry.title: Applied Technology MicroBee (mbee)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

MicroBee (or Micro Bee) was a series of networkable home computers by Applied Technology, which became publicly listed company MicroBee Systems Limited soon after its release.

The MicroBee's most distinctive features are its user configurable video display (capable of mimicking the displays of other computers and devices including the TRS-80, Sorcerer and SOL20 with later colour and graphic models 40 and 80 column terminals, Super-80, ZX Spectrum, early arcade machines, Amstrad CPC 464) and its battery backed non-volatile RAM and small size allowing it to be powered off, transported, and powered back on and resume activities on the currently loaded program or document.

It was originally packaged as a two board unit with the lower "baseboard" containing all components except the system memory which was mounted on the upper "core board".

entry.title: LÖVE (love)
entry.content:
for Retrobat only

 

LÖVE (or Love2D) is an open-source cross-platform engine for developing 2D video games. The engine is written in C++ and uses Lua as its scripting language. It is published under the zlib license.

The API provided by the engine gives access to the video and sound functions of the host machine through the libraries SDL and OpenGL, or since version 0.10 also OpenGL ES 2 and 3. Fonts can be rendered by the FreeType engine.
It also provides a basic "sandbox" management of the files in order to avoid giving access to all its disk to the executed games.
In July 2018, it was the 10th game engine most used by independents on the site itch.io, holding a 1.97% share.

entry.title: VTech Laser 310 (laser310)
entry.content:
for Batocera

 

VTech Laser 310 (also known as VZ-310). It is an all-in-one computer with a Z80, 3.54 MHz microprocessor. VTech (short for Video Technology Ltd.) was a Hong Kong electronics company that also sold the Laser in other countries through various retail chains. The Laser 310 was sold by Dick Smith Electronics , for example, so instead of VTech the Laser 310 was then called the Dick Smith Laser VZ-310 or VZ-310 for short (sold from 1983 to 1989). The Laser 310 is comparable to the previous model Laser200 (VZ-200), except for a modified keyboard and a rather unusual memory size of 18 KiB (2 KiB of which is video RAM) and is fully compatible with it. The machine ran basic games on the cartridge, such as Hoppy (Frogger's version), Cosmic Rescue (Scramble), VZ Invaders (Space Invaders), Dawn Patrol (Chopper) and Moon Patrol.

Technical specifications:
- Processor: Z80A processor, 3.54 MHz
- RAM: 16KiB
- RAM: 2KiB
- Motorola 6807 video processor
- Text resolution: 32 x 16 characters (8 colors)
- Graphics resolution: 128 x 64 pixels (4 colors)
